ygData.subject: Re: a Cantera paper + answers to some questions
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Dave, About how much longer do you think it will be b4 you release the lastest version? Paul ... almost ... mechanism ... the buildwin ... describing ...

Hi Dave,
About how much longer do you think it will be b4 you release the 
lastest version?

Paul

--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
> The best thing may be to wait for the latest version, which I am 
almost 
> ready to release.  It will probably be ready in a day or two.
> 
> 
> On Jan 30, 2004, at 3:35 PM, y2kpac wrote:
> 
> > Dave,
> > You've help me some ways in getting the surface_reaction 
mechanism
> > features figures out.  Looks like I got the bugs out of the .cti
> > file, but now I am getting a "Segmentation violation" error from
> > Matlab. I am told:
> > "This error was detected while a MEX-file was running."
> >
> > And the error seems to be traced back to
> > "Error in ==> C:\Program~1\matlab_sv13
> > \toolbox\matlab\cantera\ctmethods.dll"
> >
> > In trying to figure this out, I checked older usergroup messages.
> > Following your instructions in an email from last year (below), I
> > proceeded to try and rebuild the matlab toolbax using 
the 'buildwin'
> > command.  another error returned says:
> > "  C:\PROGRAM~1\MATLAB_SV13\BIN\WIN32\MEX.PL:
> > Error: 'private/onedimmethods.cpp' not found."
> >
> > I'm lost.
> >
> > Could you help me.
> > Paul
> >
> > --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "Dave Goodwin" <dgoodwin@c...> 
wrote:
> >>
> >> Some of you may be interested in a short paper I wrote 
describing
> >> Cantera for the upcoming Paris Electrochemical Society CVD
> > meeting. The
> >> paper is:
> >>
> >> D. G. Goodwin, "An open-source, extensible software suite for 
CVD
> >> process simulation," Proceedings of CVD XVI and EuroCVD 
Fourteen,
> >> Electrochemical Society, 2003 (in press).
> >>
> >> A preprint is available at
> >> http://blue.caltech.edu/cantera_dist/doc/cantera_ecs2003.pdf.
> >>
> >>
> >> Here are a few answers to recent questions:
> >>
> >> 1. I haven't installed Visual Studio .NET yet, so don't know if
> > there
> >> are issues getting Cantera to compile with it.
> >>
> >> 2. Cantera may not work with Matlab 5 (haven't tried it). Also, 
if
> > you
> >> are using a Matlab 6 version other than the one used to build 
the
> > Matlab
> >> toolbox in the release, you will need to rebuild the Matlab
> > toolbox.
> >> This can be done from within Matlab. You need a C compiler
> > configured to
> >> work in Matlab (do 'mex -setup'). Go to the Cantera toolbox
> > directory,
> >> and type 'buildwin' or 'buildunix'.
> >>
> >> 3. The new version of Cantera no longer requires setting
> > environment
> >> variables under Windows. (But for what its worth, in Windows 98
> > you have
> >> to edit AUTOEXEC.BAT and reboot. A better solution: upgrade to 
Win
> > 2000
> >> or Win XP...)
> >>
> >> 4. Chemical equilibrium calculations require a sufficient 
number of
> >> species in the reaction mechanism. Otherwise, 
method 'equilibrate'
> > will
> >> fail with an error message. At a minimum, you need as many 
species
> > as
> >> elements, and these must span 'element space.' That is, any 
mixture
> >> elemental composition must be achievable for some set of species
> > mole
> >> fractions.
> >>
> >> Also, compositions that correspond to exactly stoichiometric
> > combustion
> >> often cause 'equilibrate' to fail to converge, since the
> > equilibrium
> >> composition is a very sensitive function of equivalence ratio
> > here. The
> >> solution is to move away a very small amount from this 
composition.
> >
> >
> >
> >
